questions.question_text: What must be stated on the AOC?
questions.solution: Registration markings of all aeroplanes; Aerodrome operating minima for all aerodromes cleared for use

questions.question_text: The convergency of the meridians through M and N which are in the Southern hemisphere is 12°. If the rhumb line track from M to N is 249°(T), what is the great circle track: a. from M to N?
The great circle bearing of position B in latitude 30°00'S from position A (30°00'S 165°00'E) is 100°(T). What is: a. The great circle track from B to A?
The rhumb line from position D (30°00'N 179°00'W) to position C is 090°(T). The initial great circle track from C to D is 287°(T). What is: a. The great circle track from D to C?
A and B are in the same hemisphere. The initial great circle track from B to A is 268°(T) and the initial great circle track from A to B is 092°(T). i) In which hemisphere are A and B?
C and D are in the same hemisphere. The initial great circle track from C to D is 063°(T) and the rhumb line track from D to C is 240°(T). i) In which hemisphere are C and D?
Position X 64°00'S 11°50'W. Position Y 64°00'S 05°10'W. Give: a. The convergency between the meridians of X and Y.
At which latitude is the departure in NM between two points equal to: i. their difference in longitude in minutes?
At latitude 52°N, i. what is the departure between the meridians of 136°16'W and 43°44'E?

Aircraft S leaves position 36°N 10°E at 1522 hours, and flies a rhumb line track of 090°(T) at ground speed 470 kt until it reaches the 13°E meridian when it turns onto a track of 180°(T) at a ground speed of 460 kt.
Aircraft T leaves position 30°N 10°E at 1522 hours and flies a rhumb line track of 090°(T) at ground speed 150 kt.
1. Which aircraft reaches position 30°N 13°E first?
2. At what time does this occur?
3. Give the position of the other aircraft at this time. 1. Which aircraft reaches position 30°N 13°E first?
In Question 3, at what longitudes and in what direction would the Great Circle cross the Equator assuming: initial direction is east from the northern vertex?
What is the change of latitude between the following positions:- a. 52°15'N to 39°35'N
questions.chapter_title: Great Circles, Rhumb Lines & Directions on the Earth

questions.question_text: An aircraft is to fly from position 72°00'N 002°30'E to position 72°00'N 177°30'W on the shortest possible route. a. Give the initial (True) track direction
questions.chapter_title: Great Circles, Rhumb Lines & Directions on the Earth

questions.question_text: What is the position of the Rhumb Line between 2 points relative to the Great Circle between the same points if the points are: a. In the Northern hemisphere?
questions.chapter_title: Great Circles, Rhumb Lines & Directions on the Earth
questions.solution: Nearer the Equator (South of the Great Circle)

questions.question_text: A Lambert's conformal chart extends from 29°N to 45°N. Standard parallels are at 31°N and 43°N. Chart convergency is ch. Long ×0.6. On this chart is the scale at 43°N the same, greater or less than the scale at: i. 45°N

Using the same chart as Question 1, a straight line track on this chart from A (40°N 12°E) to C which is at 18°W passes through B. The direction of this track is 292°(T) at A and 283°(T) at B. a. What is the longitude of B?

A Lambert's Conformal chart extends from 42°S to 64°S. Chart convergency is ch.Long ×0.8. A straight line track on this chart from K (48°S 178°E) to M at longitude 152°W passes through L. The direction of this track at K is 102°(T) and at L is 096°(T). a. What is the longitude of position L?
The scale of a Mercator chart is 1:5 107 200 in latitude 47N. a. What distance in NM does one inch on the chart represent in 47N ?
On a Mercator chart a line drawn along the parallel of 60N, and measuring 4 inches, represents a distance of 200 km. a. Give the scale at 60N as a representative fraction.
The scale of a Mercator chart is 1:2 179 000 at the Equator. a. What is the spacing in centimetres between meridians 10° apart ?
A Mercator chart has a scale of 1:3000000 at 60N. a. In what latitude is the scale:
questions.solution: At the Equator the scale is 1:6 000 000

questions.question_text: An aircraft leaves A to fly to B, 95 NM distance. Having flown 35 NM, the aircraft position is found from a 'pinpoint' (a geographical point over which the aircraft has flown); the pinpoint is 7 NM right of track. a. What is the track error?

An aircraft is flying from Oxford to Cambridge, planned track 074°(M) distance 70 NM, heading 065°(M). Having flown 30 NM, the pilot 'pinpoints' the aircraft position overhead Cranfield, 4 NM left of planned track. a. What is the track error overhead Cranfield?

An aircraft is flying from Norwich to Oxford, planned track 250°(M), distance 96 NM, heading 260°(M), ground speed 180 kt. The aircraft departs Norwich at 1000 hrs. At 1012, the aircraft is overhead Ely, 3 NM right of planned track. Use the 1:60 to estimate the following. a. What was the planned drift?
Using the detail in questions 2-4, what rates of descent (ROD) are required to maintain the glide slopes in: a. question 2 if ground speed is 120 kt
questions.chapter_title: Other Applications of the 1 in 60 Rule

questions.question_text: You are flying an aircraft into Gioia Del Colle, Italy, on a glide slope of 2.5°. Having had a hydraulic failure, you cannot select any flaps. You approach at 220 kt TAS and have a headwind component of 10 kt. a. What rate of descent do you need to maintain the glide slope?
questions.chapter_title: Other Applications of the 1 in 60 Rule

questions.question_text: You are flying an airway with a centre line QDM of 137°(M) towards VOR/DME 'A'. Your RMI reads 141°(M)/DME 90 NM. a. Are you left or right of centre line?
questions.chapter_title: Other Applications of the 1 in 60 Rule

On a chart 14.8 centimetres represents 20 nautical miles on the ground a. Give the chart scale as a representative fraction

questions.question_text: When LMT at 4600N 00830W is 2300 on the 9th May, what is the LMT and local date at: a. 4600N 10830W?
The time is 1300 UTC on 1st April. Calculate the LMT and local date at: a. 5430N 00715E
At 3000N 4630E the time is 0300 LMT. What is the time at 6000N 01615W in: a. UTC?
At 1400 UTC on 6th November what is the Standard Time at the following locations: a. Iraq
For position 3000S 12414E on 9th August, what is the LMT of: a. Sunrise

What is the meaning of the following symbols which appear in the Air Almanac Extract?
i) ii) iii) ⊙ i) ⊙
questions.solution: Sun remains continuously above the horizon.

questions.question_text: For PERTH (3157S 11557E) WESTERN AUSTRALIA on 3rd January:- a. What is the LMT of sunrise?
For BUENOS AIRES (3500S 05229W) ARGENTINA:- a. Give the UTC of sunrise on 9th September
At 1500 UTC on 4th July, what is the Standard Time at the places listed below? a. NEW YORK, USA (Daylight Saving Time).
What is the UTC and date at the times shown below? a. 0400 Standard Time on 5th November in MADRID (4026N 00332W) SPAIN?
What is the World Health Organization's definition of alcoholism?
questions.book_name: CAE Oxford Human Performance and Limitations
questions.solution: "When the excessive use of alcohol repeatedly damages a person's physical, mental or social life"

questions.question_text: Frequency: 198 kHz. Calculate Wavelength and Frequency Band.
questions.explanation: Using the formula: wavelength = speed of light / frequency. Speed of light = 3 × 10⁸ m/s. Wavelength = (3 × 10⁸) / (198 × 10³) = 1515 m. Frequency band: LF (Low Frequency, 30-300 kHz).

questions.question_text: Wavelength: 2.7 m. Calculate Frequency and Frequency Band.
questions.explanation: Using the formula: frequency = speed of light / wavelength. Frequency = (3 × 10⁸) / 2.7 = 111.1 × 10⁶ Hz = 111.1 MHz. Frequency band: VHF (Very High Frequency, 30-300 MHz).

questions.question_text: Frequency: 5.025 GHz. Calculate Wavelength and Frequency Band.
questions.explanation: Using the formula: wavelength = speed of light / frequency. Wavelength = (3 × 10⁸) / (5.025 × 10⁹) = 0.0597 m = 5.97 cm. Frequency band: SHF (Super High Frequency, 3-30 GHz).

questions.question_text: Wavelength: 137.5 m. Calculate Frequency and Frequency Band.
questions.explanation: Using the formula: frequency = speed of light / wavelength. Frequency = (3 × 10⁸) / 137.5 = 2.1818 × 10⁶ Hz = 2181.8 kHz. Frequency band: MF (Medium Frequency, 300-3000 kHz).

questions.question_text: Frequency: 137.5 MHz. Calculate Wavelength and Frequency Band.
questions.explanation: Using the formula: wavelength = speed of light / frequency. Wavelength = (3 × 10⁸) / (137.5 × 10⁶) = 2.18 m. Frequency band: VHF (Very High Frequency, 30-300 MHz).

questions.question_text: Wavelength: 3 km. Calculate Frequency and Frequency Band.
questions.explanation: Using the formula: frequency = speed of light / wavelength. Frequency = (3 × 10⁸) / (3 × 10³) = 100 × 10³ Hz = 100 kHz. Frequency band: LF (Low Frequency, 30-300 kHz).

questions.question_text: Frequency: 329 MHz. Calculate Wavelength and Frequency Band.
questions.explanation: Using the formula: wavelength = speed of light / frequency. Wavelength = (3 × 10⁸) / (329 × 10⁶) = 0.912 m = 91.2 cm. Frequency band: UHF (Ultra High Frequency, 300-3000 MHz).

questions.question_text: Wavelength: 29 cm. Calculate Frequency and Frequency Band.
questions.explanation: Using the formula: frequency = speed of light / wavelength. Frequency = (3 × 10⁸) / 0.29 = 1.034 × 10⁹ Hz = 1034 MHz. Frequency band: UHF (Ultra High Frequency, 300-3000 MHz).

questions.question_text: Frequency: 500 kHz. Calculate Wavelength and Frequency Band.
questions.explanation: Using the formula: wavelength = speed of light / frequency. Wavelength = (3 × 10⁸) / (500 × 10³) = 600 m. Frequency band: MF (Medium Frequency, 300-3000 kHz).

questions.question_text: Wavelength: 5 cm. Calculate Frequency and Frequency Band.
questions.explanation: Using the formula: frequency = speed of light / wavelength. Frequency = (3 × 10⁸) / 0.05 = 6 × 10⁹ Hz = 6 GHz. Frequency band: SHF (Super High Frequency, 3-30 GHz).

questions.question_text: Using the CDI shown, what is the aircraft's QDR? (Figure 8.19)
questions.explanation: This question requires visual analysis of a Course Deviation Indicator (CDI) display. The QDR (magnetic bearing from the station) is determined by reading the radial from the VOR display. [Note: This question requires Figure 8.19 from the source material]

questions.question_text: Using the CDI shown, what is the aircraft's QDM? (Figure 8.20)
questions.explanation: This question requires visual analysis of a Course Deviation Indicator (CDI) display. The QDM (magnetic bearing to the station) is the reciprocal of the QDR. [Note: This question requires Figure 8.20 from the source material]

questions.question_text: Using the HSI shown, what is the aircraft's QDR? (Figure 8.21)
questions.explanation: This question requires visual analysis of a Horizontal Situation Indicator (HSI) display. The QDR is read from the VOR radial indication. [Note: This question requires Figure 8.21 from the source material]

questions.question_text: Using the HSI shown, what is the aircraft's QDM? (Figure 8.22)
questions.explanation: This question requires visual analysis of a Horizontal Situation Indicator (HSI) display. The QDM is the reciprocal of the QDR shown. [Note: This question requires Figure 8.22 from the source material]

questions.question_text: What is the effect of airwash on airspeed indicators?
questions.solution: Airwash can cause airspeed indicators to read inaccurately, typically showing higher than actual airspeed due to the increased dynamic pressure from propeller wash or jet exhaust.
questions.answer: Airwash can cause airspeed indicators to read inaccurately, typically showing higher than actual airspeed due to the increased dynamic pressure from propeller wash or jet exhaust.

questions.question_text: Explain the relationship between pressure gradient and wind speed.
questions.solution: Wind speed is directly proportional to the pressure gradient. A steeper pressure gradient (closer isobars) results in stronger winds, while a weak gradient (widely spaced isobars) produces light winds.
questions.answer: Wind speed is directly proportional to the pressure gradient. A steeper pressure gradient (closer isobars) results in stronger winds, while a weak gradient (widely spaced isobars) produces light winds.

questions.question_text: Define airwash and explain its effect on aircraft instruments.
questions.solution: Airwash is the distortion of airflow caused by propeller or jet engine exhaust. It affects airspeed indicators by creating false dynamic pressure readings, typically showing higher than actual airspeed.
questions.answer: Airwash is the distortion of airflow caused by propeller or jet engine exhaust. It affects airspeed indicators by creating false dynamic pressure readings, typically showing higher than actual airspeed.

questions.question_text: What is pressure gradient? How does it affect wind patterns?
questions.solution: Pressure gradient is the rate of change of pressure over distance. Strong gradients create strong winds, while weak gradients produce light winds. Wind flows from high to low pressure areas.
questions.answer: Pressure gradient is the rate of change of pressure over distance. Strong gradients create strong winds, while weak gradients produce light winds. Wind flows from high to low pressure areas.
